author: Chelsea Duff
title: Apparently there’s a massive battle about the right way to store ketchup
text:
Apparently there’s a massive battle about the right way to store ketchup So this is new information for us, but it seems like people on Twitter have really strong feelings about ketchup. And we guess that makes sense seeing as ketchup is one of the top favorite condiments ( beat out this past year only by Sriracha ). 
After uncovering the best way to get ketchup out of the bottle , we didn’t think there were many more condiment discoveries to be had. But it turns out there was at least one left: Twitter just discovered that people seriously disagree about where to store their condiments. 
It’s fridge vs. pantry for ketchup storage . A photo posted by Heinz Ketchup (@heinzketchup_us) on Feb 7, 2016 at 3:50pm PST 
And people are getting fired up. It all started back in January with this tweet. 
where does ketchup belong
— vic (@vicidc_) January 24, 2017 Fridge won by a long-shot, but don’t think that means pantry-supporters don’t have equally strong opinions. 
Ketchup doesn't go in the fridge.
Ketchup doesn't go in the fridge.
Ketchup doesn't go in the fridge.
Ketchup doesn't go in the fridge.
— Doug Gimmedome (@jabbjones) January 25, 2017 One observant Twitter user had an important insight to share. 
@vicidc_ pic.twitter.com/OQZkPrGCt5 
— Brifi (@BrianForschler1) January 25, 2017 But that didn’t change anyone’s mind once it had already been made up. 
@BrianForschler1 @vicidc_ "for best results" my ass it tastes the same 
— VK (@VKwutsgood) January 25, 2017 Quickly, things devolved into chaos with Twitter users coming at each other and getting into fights. 
@leos_haus @vicidc_ 
You use the ketchup instantly after opening a packet. Bottles that have been opened need to be stores in the fridge
— GalaxyMonstero Ⓜ️ (@GalaxyMonstero) February 5, 2017 @leos_haus @vicidc_ 
They dont need to be, but stores recommend it because bacteria starts to grow after being opened when in pantry.
— GalaxyMonstero Ⓜ️ (@GalaxyMonstero) February 5, 2017 It even drove families apart. 
Asked Dad whether he keeps his Ketchup in the fridge or the cupboard and this is his response... pic.twitter.com/LJJmJlL71F 
— amy (@amyheppolette) February 2, 2017 Lines were drawn in the sand, and people took their sides. 
I could never be with someone that keeps their ketchup in the cupboard not the fridge.
— bee (@pinealpples) February 2, 2017 ppl who put their ketchup in the fridge - dont trust em xx
— rosie (@KIRKPATRlCK) February 1, 2017 If you keep ketchup in the pantry you're an animal and there's no room for you in civilized society
— luke (@lukelton) February 2, 2017 That’s when the professionals got dragged into the fray. 
The football professionals, that is. Not the condiment professionals. (We already know where Heinz stands on the subject.)
. @YGSIU #NorthNoise pic.twitter.com/DpdIwqxqt5 
— NFL Canada (@NFLCanada) February 1, 2017 . @YGSIU #AskThePats pic.twitter.com/fkTu2y7I2l 
— NFL Canada (@NFLCanada) February 2, 2017 Amidst the drama, some chose to opt out entirely. 
Me during debates about sexuality, finance, expensive dates, and ketchup pic.twitter.com/3iw7zKiidq 
— Faith Trill (@LowKei_) February 5, 2017 And others just kept doing their own thing. 
My 6 year old just called ketchup potato sauce pic.twitter.com/jjHKi1s87i 
— Officer Hern (@FairbornSRO) February 4, 2017 Honestly, we’re just glad nobody’s brought “catsup” into the mix. 
That’s one discussion we don’t need to have. 
In the meantime, we’ll go back to chowing down on our chicken wings . But don’t get us started on ranch vs. blue cheese.
